Lessig was not a record show he was a constitutional law professor I was in

I did my venture capital work investing in six apart and technorati and stuff that was when I thought that blogging platforms and social media was gonna be a really it still is but that that was the way to do the impact and then as I started to think about it and think more broadly I realized that well we still have these large institutions that do news and that blogging by itself isn't gonna fix everything and so that so I think there was a period if you remember when and I don't know which side you were on the technological solar boy yeah it was kind of when you know we were declaring independence cyberspace was independent and the end of the sovereign nation and professional journalists be damned we're gonna we were gonna take over everything and it turns out we know now that this is this is much more complex and and that it also is it sustaining me so so so now that I realized it was complex I realized I had to understand it better and that just doing startups wasn't the way that we were gonna fix this problem or to help us get through this valley that seems like it was showing up and so and and one of the things that I realized that when I was watching how blogs took off and why they took off and this ties to something that Nicholas Negroponte the founder than me that I've talked about when I was talking to him about the

IT company building a humongous content management system for a bunch of people who didn't want to be bothered by technology right and and Nicholas's version when he talks about the Media

Lab and what we what they're what we are doing here is that where the the the the design and the engineering and the science and the art all come together so he uses example of photography being a very interesting development process because the photographers were also the people working on the chemistry and the glass and the mechanics so the photographers were very involved in the evolution of the camera and so it continues to be very sort of artful in its in its progress whereas television and and in print there was a separation and there's two reasons for the separation one is the editorial has to be isolated from the business otherwise it's going to be tainted it's kind of like tenured faculty right you've got to be completely pure and so if you're not bothered by the business side you don't actually get your hands under the hood and understand how the thing works you don't worry about the technology won't worry about the money so it's very difficult for the people who were actually using this stuff to innovate because they don't understand how the thing works and and I think that's true with television it's true with a lot of the other other even non news media you've separated out right what I want to I want to jump on that Nicholas

Silicon Valley it really was when the military complex shutdown and you've had a lot of really smart unemployed people who were forced to do new things right so so I'm not saying that unemployment is the driver of everything but there definitely needs to be a class of entrepreneurial people that free up for a certain category of innovation happen now the difference though is in a question is technical people who lose their jobs can immediately start building a technical thing one of the problems I find with unemployed journalists is that they haven't been trained and don't understand the technology or the business enough and it's hard for them and I think this is why these kinds of meet is important because I think that the success cases are going to be multiple people co-founded things but but but I do think that that the technical people underestimate the complexity of journalism and civics and the the journalists tend to underestimate the importance of understanding the technology and I do think that it's getting better though I mean I think these kinds of meetings I look at but you know but in but still in baby steps
